page.title: 05BIRDS OF THE S. DOWNS
page.content: The birds habitat has suffered from ploughing & clearing. Game birds regularly seen & plentiful are pheasants, which are bred by landowners. Partridge are scarce in 1985 but the cold spring this year could explain this. The most common birds of prey are Kestrel & Sparrow-hawk. Rooks & Lapwings join the flocks of Black-Headed Gulls that follow the plough to feast on the insects in the newly turned soil. By far the most numerous of the small birds is the lark, which nests on the ground & soars high above the edge of the Downs. Siskins & Goldcrests appear to like the conifers & may be seen flitting in & out among the branches. Woodpigeons are numerous, but cuckoos are now much less common.
